episodeTitle: Ultimate Test of the Ordeal of Iron! The White-Barbed Death Match!!
description: Ohm creates a barbed wire cage that traps all combatants in a deadly arena. Meanwhile, inside the giant snake Nola, Nami and Gan Fall discover that Luffy is causing the creature's violent rampage. Raki is defeated by Enel as Wyper watches helplessly, while Zoro prepares to face Ohm.

events.title: White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch Created
events.description: At Ohm's command, Holy runs around the battlefield and triggers pressure plates that release Iron Cloud traps. These form a massive dome of barbed wire that completely encases the Upper Ruins area, trapping all combatants inside with no escape. The cage is made of Iron Cloud - as strong as metal but with the flexibility of clouds.
events.significance: This creates the ultimate battle arena for the Ordeal of Iron, forcing all fighters into close-quarters combat with no retreat possible. The technique demonstrates Ohm's mastery of Iron Cloud manipulation and sets up the climactic battles to come.

quotes.text: This is the ultimate test of the Ordeal of Iron - the White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch!
quotes.speaker: Ohm
quotes.context: Activating the barbed wire cage to trap all fighters

events.title: Raki Confronts Enel
events.description: Raki arrives at the barbed wire cage to deliver a message to Wyper about Kamakiri's defeat. Upon seeing Enel, she attempts to shoot him with her rifle, but as a Logia Devil Fruit user, the bullets pass harmlessly through his lightning body. Enel mocks her futile attack.
events.significance: This moment demonstrates the overwhelming power gap between Enel and normal fighters, showing how helpless even brave warriors are against his Logia abilities. It builds tension as Raki faces impossible odds.

quotes.text: You think such primitive weapons can harm a god?
quotes.speaker: Enel
quotes.context: After Raki's bullets pass through his body

events.title: Enel Defeats Raki
events.description: Enel unleashes a powerful electric attack that strikes Raki, electrocuting her and leaving her unconscious. Wyper watches from behind the barbed wire cage, unable to help. In his rage and frustration, he grabs the iron wires with his bare hands, cutting himself as he desperately tries to break through to save her.
events.significance: This moment showcases Wyper's emotional depth and the toll of four hundred years of Shandian suffering. His helpless rage while watching another comrade fall to Enel demonstrates the personal stakes of the conflict and develops his character beyond just being a warrior.

events.title: Wyper's Four Hundred Years of Hate
events.description: As Wyper grips the barbed wire in fury, the episode emphasizes that he carries four hundred years of accumulated anger and grief from the Shandian people's displacement. His rage isn't just personal - it represents generations of his people who lost their homeland when Upper Yard was taken from them.
events.significance: This moment provides crucial context for Wyper's seemingly reckless behavior throughout the arc. It establishes that the Skypiea conflict isn't just about treasure or territory - it's about historical injustice, stolen land, and the weight of ancestral memory that drives the Shandian warriors.

events.title: Inside Nola's Stomach
events.description: Nami, Gan Fall, Aisa, and Pierre find themselves inside the giant snake Nola's stomach after being swallowed. They discuss their predicament and search for a way to escape from inside the creature. The stomach is shown as a cavernous space with digestive fluids.
events.significance: This establishes the secondary location for this episode's events and sets up the discovery of Luffy. The scene provides comic relief while also building tension about their survival.

quotes.text: We need to find a way out of here before we get digested!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Realizing they're trapped in Nola's stomach

events.title: Discovery of Luffy Inside Nola
events.description: Nami, Gan Fall, and Aisa discover that Luffy is also inside Nola's stomach. They realize that Luffy's fighting and movement inside the snake is what has been causing Nola to rampage violently across Upper Yard. Luffy appears oblivious to the danger, treating the situation casually.
events.significance: This revelation explains the mystery of why Nola has been acting so erratically. It's a classic Luffy moment - his antics inadvertently causing chaos while he remains cheerfully unaware. The scene adds humor while resolving a plot thread about Nola's unusual behavior.

quotes.text: Oh hey guys! I was wondering where everyone went!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Casually greeting the others inside Nola's stomach

quotes.text: YOU'RE the reason this snake is going crazy?!
quotes.speaker: Nami

events.title: Zoro and Wyper Clash
events.description: Zoro and Wyper, both determined to reach Nola to rescue their trapped allies, end up fighting each other as they race toward the giant snake. Despite having a common enemy in Enel and Ohm, their different methods and lack of coordination lead them to conflict. Both are driven by the need to save their friends.
events.significance: This moment highlights the fractured nature of the resistance against Enel - even those who should be allies fight among themselves. It showcases both warriors' determination while demonstrating how the chaos of battle prevents effective cooperation.

quotes.text: Get out of my way! I'm going to save Aisa!
quotes.speaker: Wyper
quotes.context: Confronting Zoro while heading toward Nola

quotes.text: I don't have time for this - Nami and the old man are in that snake!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

events.title: Ohm Attacks Zoro and Wyper
events.description: Taking advantage of the distraction caused by Aisa and Nami being swallowed by Nola, Ohm launches an attack on both Zoro and Wyper. His Iron Cloud sword morphs and extends, demonstrating the versatile and deadly nature of his weapon. Holy, his dog, also engages, using martial arts techniques.
events.significance: This marks the beginning of the true Ordeal of Iron battle. Ohm's attack forces Zoro and Wyper to deal with an immediate threat, intensifying the already chaotic battlefield. The scene showcases Ohm's combat abilities and strategic thinking.

events.title: Ohm's Iron Cloud Abilities Displayed
events.description: Ohm demonstrates the full versatility of his Eisen (Iron Cloud) weapon. The blade morphs between different forms: extending as a whip for long-range attacks, solidifying into a wall for defense, and changing into various shapes to adapt to combat situations. The weapon combines the strength of iron with the flexibility of clouds.
events.significance: This reveals the true nature of Ohm's unique fighting style and why he's considered one of Enel's strongest priests. The Iron Cloud technology showcases Skypiea's unique combat abilities that differ from anything seen in the Blue Seas.

quotes.text: Iron Cloud is the perfect weapon - it has the hardness of steel but moves like the wind.
quotes.speaker: Ohm

events.title: Zoro Decides to Fight Ohm
events.description: Zoro makes the strategic decision to confront Ohm directly before attempting to rescue Nami and Gan Fall from Nola. He recognizes that Ohm will continue to be a threat and obstacle, so defeating him first is the priority. Zoro prepares his three-sword style for the coming battle.
events.significance: This shows Zoro's tactical thinking and prioritization in battle. Rather than rushing blindly to rescue his friends, he understands that eliminating the immediate threat is necessary. This decision sets up the climactic Zoro vs. Ohm confrontation that will continue in the next episode.

quotes.text: I can't save anyone if you're in my way. I'll finish you off first!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Committing to fight Ohm before rescuing Nami

events.title: Ohm's Mantra Ability Revealed
events.description: It's revealed that Ohm possesses Mantra (Observation Haki), allowing him to sense his opponents' movements and locations even through walls and obstacles. This gives him a significant advantage in combat, as he can predict attacks and locate enemies without seeing them directly.
events.significance: This establishes Ohm as one of the more formidable priests, possessing the same precognitive ability as Enel. It raises the stakes for Zoro's fight, as he must overcome an opponent who can sense his every move. This is an important early showcase of what will later be revealed as Observation Haki.

quotes.text: With Mantra, I can sense every movement you make. There is no escape.
quotes.speaker: Ohm
quotes.context: Explaining his ability to sense Zoro's location

quotes.text: This is the ultimate test of the Ordeal of Iron - the White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch!
quotes.speaker: Ohm

quotes.text: YOU'RE the reason this snake is going crazy?!
quotes.speaker: Nami

quotes.text: I can't save anyone if you're in my way. I'll finish you off first!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

quotes.text: With Mantra, I can sense every movement you make. There is no escape.
quotes.speaker: Ohm

themes.description: The episode emphasizes Wyper's burden of carrying four hundred years of Shandian anger and grief. His reaction to Raki's defeat shows how historical trauma manifests in present-day warriors.
themes.symbolism: The barbed wire cage symbolizes how all parties are trapped by the cycle of violence and revenge stemming from past injustices.

themes.description: Zoro's calculated decision to fight Ohm first contrasts with Wyper's emotional rush to save Aisa, highlighting different approaches to the same goal of protecting loved ones.
themes.symbolism: The choice between immediate rescue and strategic elimination of threats represents different philosophies of protection.

themes.description: Raki's futile attempt to shoot Enel demonstrates the vast power gap between normal warriors and Logia Devil Fruit users, creating dramatic tension about who can possibly stop Enel.
themes.symbolism: Bullets passing through Enel's body represent the futility of conventional approaches against godlike power.

characterSpotlights.development: Wyper's depth is explored through his helpless rage as he watches Raki fall to Enel. The episode emphasizes that his anger stems from four centuries of Shandian suffering, giving context to his seemingly reckless behavior.
keyActions: Watches Raki being defeated by Enel
Grabs barbed wire with bare hands in frustration
Fights with Zoro while trying to reach Nola
quotes: Get out of my way! I'm going to save Aisa!

characterSpotlights.development: Ohm is showcased as a formidable opponent with his Iron Cloud manipulation and Mantra abilities. His strategic use of the White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch demonstrates his tactical thinking.
keyActions: Commands Holy to create the barbed wire cage
Takes advantage of distractions to attack Zoro and Wyper
quotes: This is the ultimate test of the Ordeal of Iron - the White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch!
With Mantra, I can sense every movement you make. There is no escape.

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro demonstrates tactical maturity by choosing to eliminate the threat before attempting rescue. His focus and determination showcase his growth as a warrior who thinks strategically.
keyActions: Fights with Wyper while heading to Nola
Decides to defeat Ohm before rescuing Nami
Prepares for serious combat against Ohm
quotes: I don't have time for this - Nami and the old man are in that snake!
I can't save anyone if you're in my way. I'll finish you off first!

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy's oblivious behavior inside Nola provides comic relief. His casual attitude about being swallowed demonstrates his characteristic lack of concern for danger.
keyActions: Fights inside Nola's stomach causing it to rampage
Casually greets the others when discovered
quotes: Oh hey guys! I was wondering where everyone went!

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extended the scenes of conflict between Zoro and Wyper, adding more choreography to their brief clash that was shorter in the manga.
Additional dialogue was added to emphasize Wyper's emotional state and the weight of the four hundred years of Shandian history.
The scene inside Nola's stomach was extended with more interaction between Luffy, Nami, Gan Fall, and Aisa for comedic effect.

trivia.fact: This episode marks the debut of one of Ohm's signature techniques, the White-Barbed Iron Deathmatch, which has a stated survival rate of 0%.
The episode adapts chapters 270 (pages 2-19) and 271 (pages 2-8), covering about 1.5 manga chapters.
Holy, Ohm's dog, is one of the few animals in One Piece shown to use sophisticated martial arts techniques, specifically boxing.
The episode aired with a TV rating of 12.4%, ranking #5 in its timeslot in Japan.
The ending song 'A to Z' by ZZ was in its 9th episode of usage out of its total 13-episode run (episodes 169-181).

sources.title: A to Z | One Piece Wiki
